definition:
A square matrix $A$ is called a [*Hurwitz matrix*]{} if all eigenvalues
of $A$ have strictly negative real part, $Re[\lambda_i] < 0$; $A$ is
also called a [*stability matrix*]{}, because the feedback system
$$\dot x = A x$$ is stable.

If $G(s)$ is a (matrix-valued) transfer function, then $G$ is called
Hurwitz if the poles of all elements of $G$ have negative real part.
Note that it is not necessary that $G(s)$, for a specific argument $s$,
be a Hurwitz matrix — it need not even be square. The connection is that
if $A$ is a Hurwitz matrix, then the dynamical system $$\begin{aligned}
  \dot x(t) &=& A x(t) + B u(t) \\
  y(t) &=& C x(t) + D u(t)\end{aligned}$$ has a Hurwitz transfer
function.

Reference: Hassan K. Khalil, [*Nonlinear Systems*]{}, Prentice Hall,
2002
